moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6: The Marshall attack, wherein Black sacs a pawn for a strong attack. It is surprising how much compensation Black gets for the pawn, but the variation is well known since the famous inaugural game Capablanca-Marshall in 1918.
moves.9. exd5 Nxd5 10. Nxe5 Nxe5 11. Rxe5 c6 1: All book to here. Now White has a choice of several moves: 13 Bxd5, Re1 and Re2 being the main ones.
moves.13. Re2: I've played against the Marshall many times, both OTB and in correspondence. The 13 Re1 lines are OK with me, but I wanted to see what my opponent had ready against the less used text.
moves.13... Qh4 14. g3 Qh3 15. Qf1 Qh5 16. f3: Here is where books leave us behind.
moves.19. Rxe8 Rxe8 20. Bxd5+: When f5-f4 becomes a real threat is the time to make this exchange.
With 2 pawns up, a blunder ruins things. After 25 Re1! in case of 25...Rxe1  26 Qxe1 Black cannot reply 26...Qxf3 due to 27 Qe8 mate. And if 25...Bxf1, then 26 Rxe8  Qxe8 27 Kxf1 leaves White just two pawns up with a won endgame.
moves.25... Bxf1 26. Kxf1 Qxf3+ 27. Qf2 Qd3+ 2: Now Black has the extra pawn, and White is looking to draw.
White has restored material equality, and now the endless checks will lead to the draw.
